description: OPIM 101 explores a variety of common quantitative modeling problems that arise frequently in business settings, and discusses how they can be formally modeled and solved with a combination of business insight and computer-based tools. The key topics covered include capacity management, service operations, inventory control, structured decision making, constrained optimization and simulation. This course teaches how to model complex business situations and how to master tools to improve business performance. The goal is to provide a set of foundational skills useful for future coursework atWharton as well as providing an overview of problems and techniques that characterize disciplines that comprise Operations and Information Management.
name: INTRO TO OPS & INFO MGMT: Introduction to Operations and Information Management

section.name: INTRO TO OPS & INFO MGMT: Introduction to Operations and Information Management

values.comments:
OPIM 101 explores a variety of common quantitative modeling problems that arise frequently in business settings, and discusses how they can be formally modeled and solved with a combination of business insight and computer-based tools. The key topics covered include capacity management, service operations, inventory control, structured decision making, constrained optimization and simulation. This course teaches how to model complex business situations and how to master tools to improve business performance. The goal is to provide a set of foundational skills useful for future coursework at Wharton as well as providing an overview of problems and techniques that characterize disciplines that comprise Operations and Information Management. The class can be waived if the student is in a dual (Engineering + Wharton) degree program and the student must take at least one OPIM course from the following list of 200 level courses:
           - 210 Management Information Systems
           - 220 Introduction to Operations Management
           - 224 Service Operations Management
           - 290 Decision Processes
Students found the subject matter “very interesting,” “readily applicable to real world business problems,” and the material useful for future classes, like the Excel work. While “the tools are basic and very useful,” some students felt that the difficulty level could be increased. The course provides “necessary intuition for such concepts such as constraints, supply, demand, and modeling them.”
Professor Cachon was “does a great job of communicating the material and keeping the students engaged.” He is an “an excellent instructor and essentially pioneer in the field, so learning from him is not something to be taken for granted.”
The curve was very difficult because the grade spread was small. One student remarked that “it is important to keep pace with the work and learn through doing because this class teaches skills rather than content.” “The divide between lecture and recitation forces students to constantly stay on top of course concepts because within a day or two of lecture, the recitation exercises reinforce and test what was taught that week.” While a requirement for the Wharton core curriculum, students would recommend this class to non-Wharton students as well. Most students found recitations to be useful.

section.name: INTRO TO OPS & INFO MGMT: Introduction to Operations and Information Management

values.comments:
OPIM 101 explores a variety of common quantitative modeling problems that arise frequently in business settings, and discusses how they can be formally modeled and solved with a combination of business insight and computer-based tools. The key topics covered include capacity management, service operations, inventory control, structured decision-making, constrained optimization and simulation. This course teaches how to model complex business situations and how to master tools to improve business performance. The goal is to provide a set of foundational skills useful for future coursework at Wharton as well as providing an overview of problems and techniques that characterize disciplines that comprise Operations and Information Management.

	Overall, students found the structure of OPIM 101 to be “truly remarkable” and exposes students to excel work that can be applied to other Wharton courses. One student thought that it was one of the “most relevant classes at Penn.” The course is divided into two separate parts, with separate teachers as well. Students found that there was “great coordination of homework, recitation, and exams” making the course very efficiently run. However, some students remarked that the lectures were too boring or simplistic. In addition, one student noted that the large course size made it difficult to learn. Another student did not like the relationship between the two parts of the course, deeming it “inconsistent.” 
	
Students all agreed that Savin was a great professor. He is “both good at explaining concepts” and “able to demonstrate real life applicability.” One student noted that Savin is particularly funny. However, one student noted that the professor “should share more personal experience” and that he sometimes “rushed through topics.” 
	
Most students explained that this course is difficult due to the tight curves of the midterms. One student explained that there is “no partial credit on tests.” One student also noted that it is very “important to keep pace with the work in order to develop skills.” The majority of students thought the first half was a lot harder than the second. This course is offered both semesters and has no prerequisites. It is required for all Wharton students.

section.name: INTRO TO OPS & INFO MGMT: Introduction to Operations and Information Management
INTRO TO OPS & INFO MGMT: Introduction to Operations and Information Management

values.comments:
OPIM 101 explores a variety of common quantitative modeling problems that arise frequently in business settings, and discusses how they can be formally modeled and solved with a combination of business insight and computer-based tools. The key topics covered include capacity management, service operations, inventory control, structured decision making, constrained optimization and simulation. This course teaches how to model complex business situations and how to master tools to improve business performance. The goal is to provide a set of foundational skills useful for future coursework at Wharton as well as providing an overview of problems and techniques that characterize disciplines that comprise Operations and Information Management. The class can be waived if the student is in a dual (Engineering + Wharton) degree program and the student must take at least one OPIM course from the following list of 200 level courses:
           - 210 Management Information Systems
           - 220 Introduction to Operations Management
           - 224 Service Operations Management
           - 290 Decision Processes
This review was for a recitation of OPIM 101 and didn’t specify much about the course. Students appreciated that the recitation “reinforced material from lectures” and found that the recitation was a “useful” asset in learning the concepts covered in class.
Students had praise for their recitation TA, Scott Fishman. Described as a “fantastic TA,” students appreciated how Scott made recitation “engaging.” Scott was “always willing to clarify and help us out.” One student mentioned that Scott “taught the material well,” but mentioned that the number of students in recitation made Scott less “accessible as the TAs I’ve had in other classes.”
OPIM 101 is a required part of the Wharton core.

OPIM 101 explores a variety of common quantitative modeling problems that arise frequently in business settings, and discusses how they can be formally modeled and solved with a combination of business insight and computer-based tools.  The key topics covered include capacity management, service operations, inventory control, structured decision making, constrained optimization and simulation.  This course teaches how to model complex business situations and how to master tools to improve business performance. The goal is to provide a set of foundational skills useful for future coursework at Wharton as well as providing an overview of problems and techniques that characterize disciplines that comprise Operations and Information Management.

Students generally enjoyed this course, and one student said that she "learned a lot." 
One gripe that people had with the course was that working together in problem sets did not "encourage learning."

Overall, Professor Horowitz had very high ratings. According to one student, the professor is very "warm and approachable." People also had great reviews of the TA, Rebekah. She was commended for "knowing everyone's names" and students appreciated the fact that she covered "topics that would be on the recitation exercise."

OPIM 101 is a required course for Wharton classes and is recommended for "anyone interested in operations and information management."
